discussion.content: Answer is Blob, Cosmos DB for NoSQL and Azure SQL Database

Audio files - Azure Blob Storage
JSON documents - Azure Cosmos DB for NoSQL
Tabular datasets - Azure SQL Database
For tabular datasets, it should be Azure SQL Database and not Azure Data Factory.
Azure Data Factory should not be picked as an answer in this question as it has no place here

A small remark: 
JSON documents can be stored in SQL Server or SQL Database

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/sql/relational-databases/json/store-json-documents-in-sql-tables?view=sql-server-ver16

Cosmos is the right choice for JSON

Why I think that the question is about only "data storages"?
And I see only two data storages:
1. Azure Blob Storage where we can storage files and documents.
2. Azure SQL Database - where we can store tables and data.

Therefore, I think that the answer should be - Azure Blob Storage, Azure Blob Storage, Azure SQL Database.
Agree> the last one should be Database

discussion.content:
NNY
The default access tier for a new general-purpose v2 storage account is set to the hot tier by default.

An append blob is composed of blocks and is optimized for append operations. When you modify an append blob, blocks are added to the end of the blob only, via the Append Block operation. Updating or deleting of existing blocks is not supported.

Rehydrating a blob from the Archive tier can take several hours to complete.

comments.content: I am mistaken , ignore my message

For me the second should be true , I followed Bartin8tor link for append blobs and it clearly states that they are optimized for random read & writes.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/understanding-block-blobs--append-blobs--and-page-blobs

discussion.content: Optimized for random read and write - It's Page Blob

The answer is A. For NoSQL

Here's why:

Azure Cosmos DB for NoSQL supports the Core (SQL) API. This API allows you to query data stored in JSON documents using a SQL-like language.

Other APIs:

For Apache Gremlin: Used for graph databases, employs the Gremlin query language.
For MongoDB: Leverages MongoDB's query language.
For Table: Designed for storing and querying data in tables, similar to Azure Table storage.
In summary: The Cosmos DB for NoSQL API, with its SQL-like syntax, provides a familiar way to query JSON documents within Azure Cosmos DB.
False, Fales, True

False. The default access tier of an Azure Storage account is the Hot access tier.
False. Append blobs are optimized for sequential write operations, not random read and write operations.
True. Retrieving data from the Archive access tier may take several hours to complete, depending on the size of the data and the retrieval options chosen.
The Azure Cosmos DB API for NoSQL supports querying documents using SQL. This article provides a sample document and two sample SQL queries and results / found in Microsoft tutorial
Azure Cosmos DB core API is the answer but this is not in the list. Closest thing to query documents would be MongoDB API

comments.content: Core API was called SQL API formerly.

incorrect, MongoDB API using syntax e.g. db.families.find( { id: "AdressfieldFamily" }, { children: true } ). NoSQL API using syntax with SELECT statement, e.g. SELECT * FROM Products, so the correct answer is A. for NoSQL API.

discussion.content:
-Mongo DB!
Azure Cosmos DB provides multiple APIs for different workloads, and while the SQL API is used for querying Cosmos DB with SQL syntax, the MongoDB API allows you to use MongoDB's query language (which is similar to SQL in some cases) to interact with your data.

The correct answer is "for NOSQL".
NoSQL accounts provide support for querying items using the Structured Query Language (SQL) syntax, one of the most familiar and popular query languages to query JSON objects.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/choose-api

discussion.content:
Yes. Azure File Storage can be created in a storage account in Azure.
No. The Premium tier of Azure File Storage uses SSD-based hardware in a datacenter, not HDD-based.
No. The Standard tier of Azure File Storage also uses HDD-based hardware in a datacenter, not SSD-based. However, it is worth noting that both tiers of Azure File Storage offer a combination of SSDs and HDDs to optimize performance and cost.

The answers are correct.
YNN

Azure Files provides a range of storage tiers that help reduce costs by allowing you to store data at the appropriate level of performance and price. At the highest level, Azure Files offers two performance tiers: standard and premium. Standard file shares are hosted on a storage system backed by hard disk drives (HDD), while premium file shares are backed by solid-state drives (SSD) for better performance. Standard file shares have several storage tiers (transaction optimized, hot, and cool) that you can seamlessly move between to maximize the data at-rest storage and transaction prices. However, you can't move between standard and premium tiers without physically migrating your data between different storage accounts
correct answer
Batch, Streaming,Batch

Batch
Streaming
Batch

Batch, Loading data at fixed intervals (every 12 hours) aligns with batch processing, where data is collected, processed, and loaded in chunks.
Streaming, Streaming workloads handle data in real-time, processing thousands of data points per second as they are generated.
Batch, Processing data after accumulating a large number of transactions (1 million) is a characteristic of batch processing.
Corretc
Batch, Streaming,Batch

Batch, Streaming, Batch.

questions.answer_description:
Box 1: Batch -
Batch processing refers to the processing of blocks of data that have already been stored over a period of time.

Box 2: Streaming -
Stream processing is a big data technology that allows us to process data in real-time as they arrive and detect conditions within a small period of time from the point of receiving the data. It allows us to feed data into analytics tools as soon as they get generated and get instant analytics results.

Box 3: Batch -
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/architecture/data-guide/technology-choices/batch-processing
